Ta male katekismus is praşhajnami inu odgovormi sa te narmajnshe otroke u' zesarskeh, tudi zesarskeh kraleveh deshelah = Der kleine Katechismus mit Fragen und Antworten für die kleinsten Kinder der kasiral. auch kaiserl. königl. Staaten (1806)

Mali katekisem v' vprashanjih inu odgovorih sa narmajnshi otroke po zesarskih kralevih zemlah = Der kleine Katechismus mit Fragen und Antworten für die kleinsten Kinder der kaiserl. königl. Staaten (1815); Mali katekisem v' vprashanjih ino odgovorih sa manjshi otroke po zesarskih kraljevih deshelah = Der kleine Katechismus mit Fragen und Antworten für die kleinsten Kinder der kaiserl. königl. Staaten (1818, 1819, 1825); Majhini katekismus s' prashanjami inu odgovormi sa otrozhizhe v' zesarskih kralevih deshelah = Der kleine Katechismus mit Fragen und Antworten für die kleinsten Kinder der kaiserl. königl. Ljubljana : Slovenska akademija znanosti in umetnosti, 1978, pp. 15, 19; Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 61; Kokolj, Miroslav; Horvat, Bela. Prekmursko šolstvo od začetka reformacije do zloma nacizma. Murska Sobota : Pomurska založba, 1977, pp. 91; Krajnc-Vrečko, Fanika: Bakoš, Mihal (okoli 1742–1803). Slovenska biografija. Slovenska akademija znanosti in umetnosti, Znanstvenoraziskovalni center SAZU, 2013. https://www.slovenska-biografija.si/oseba/sbi133339/#novi-slovenski-biografski-leksikon (1. March 2022). Originally published in: Novi Slovenski biografski leksikon: 2. vol. B-Bla. Ed. Barbara Šterbenc Svetina et al. Ljubljana, Znanstvenoraziskovalni center SAZU, 2017;

The present work is Bakoš's reworking of Abecedarium szlowenszko, za drobno detzo, vőn szpűscheno from 1725. Kokolj and Horvat also write about the edition from 1793, which apparently has not been preserved to this day (Škafar, 1978, 15, 19 and Andoljšek, 1978, 61 and Kokolj and Horvat, 1977, 91 and Krajnc-Vrečko, 2013). The work was reprinted in 2017.

Strictly speaking, the work is not a textbook, but it nevertheless also served as lessons for schoolchildren. Bakoš himself recommended the work for such use in the preface (Kokolj and Horvat, 1977, 92).

Ljubljana : Slovenska akademija znanosti in umetnosti, 1978, pp. 48, 56; Kokolj, Miroslav; Horvat, Bela. Prekmursko šolstvo od začetka reformacije do zloma nacizma. Murska Sobota : Pomurska založba, 1977, pp. 200-202; Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj II (1869-1918). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1976, pp. 58-61.

The work was translated by Jožef Bagáry. The edition from 1871 is referred to as 'II. edition', but Škafar points out that it is: 'a translation of the second edition of the reader /.../. There is no translation of the first edition in Slovenian' (Škafar, 1978, 48, 56) .

The digitized version of the text is the third Graz edition of Parhamer's adaptation of Canisius' Catechism. The first edition from 1758, which was once kept in the library of the Benedictine monastery in Admont, is no longer preserved, whereas the second edition can be still found there. The person that most likely was the translator of the first two editions is Gregor Plohel, to whom Ilešič also attributes the translation of the third edition, which Kidrič categorically rejects and states that the author of the translation of the third edition was 'someone who was supposedly still alive in 1811 and was Šmigoč's friend.' Language and spelling also changed significantly. Thus Ilešič states: 'The first edition (from 1758) and the second edition (1764)use the Kaikavian-Croatian orthography, and the third edition (from 1777) is already written in Bohorič alphabet. The language of the first edition is almost pure Kaikavian, the language of the second edition oscillates between Croatian Kaikavian and the Styrian-Slovenian dialect, the language of the third edition has only a few traces of Kaikavian, but obviously has already signs of Western influence' (Andoljšek, 1978, 33 and Ilešič, 1906, 3 and Wester 1901, 647-648 and Ditmajer, 2019, 34-35 and Kidrič, 2013).

(1762, 1764); Katechisem tu je Bukvize Tega sprashuvanje is petshtukou zhastitega patra Petra Canisia. H' perpomaganju Vseh Gospudou Framastrou, Duhouneh vskerbnikou, Vuzhenikou: tudi otruk, inu stareishou, bratou, inu sester Bratoushine Kershanskega Navuka. Originally published in: Slovenski bijografski leksikon: 2. vol. Erberg - Hinterlechner. Izidor Cankar et al. Ljubljana, Zadružna gospodarska banka, 1926; Andoljšek, Ivan: Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana, Univerzum, 1978, 33.

Andoljšek emphasizes that 'the purpose of these editions /.../ and the content show that they were not adapted for school only. They were even less so primers, as there were no reading instructions in any of them.' Kidrič and Smolnik consider Ozbald Gutsman to be the person who most likely translated the first and not entirely reliably dated Klagenfurt edition of Parhamer's adaptation of Canisius' Catechism from the period between 1760 and 1762. The same translator (probably Gutsman, as mentioned) is almost certainly also the author of the translation in the edition from 1790. The title page of the first edition has not been preserved, so we did not add the title of the latter, but it is probably the closest to the one from 1790. For the two remaining editions from 1762 and 1764, we cannot firmly state that at this stage (Smolnik, 2011 and Kidrič, 2013 and Andoljšek, 1978, 33).

The present translation of Parhamer's reworking of Canisius' Catechism is the work of Marko Pohlin. As Andoljšek points out, the work was intended for lessons for children, but, Pohlin in the preface 'intended the catechism for parents to teach children Christian doctrine, but nowhere does it say that it was translated for school' (Andoljšek, 1978, 34).

Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 155-158; Schmidt, Vlado. Zgodovina šolstva in pedagogike na Slovenskem II. (1805 - 1848). Andoljšek points out that Dajnko's 'Abecedna knižica' (1824) /.../ was unofficial and, at least in terms of the reading material, completely unique. Since the language has East Styrian peculiarities, it was intended for local schools' (Andoljšek, 1978, 158).
Lehrbuch der Windischen Sprache : ein Versuch zur gründlichen Erlernung derselben für Deutsche, zur vollkommeneren Ketniss für Slowenen (1824)

Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 329; Kidrič, Francè: Dajnko, Peter (1787–1873). Slovenska biografija. Slovenska akademija znanosti in umetnosti, Znanstvenoraziskovalni center SAZU, 2013. http://www.slovenska-biografija.si/oseba/sbi168756/#slovenski-biografski-leksikon (15. May 2023). Originally published in: Slovenski bijografski leksikon: 1. vol. Abraham - Erberg. Izidor Cankar et al. Ljubljana, Zadružna gospodarska banka, 1925; Jožica Narat: Peter Dajnko. Lehrbuch der Windiſchen Sprache. In: Ahačič, Kozma (ur.): Slovenske slovnice in pravopisi: spletišče slovenskih slovnic in pravopisov od 1584 do danes. Različica 1.0. https://www.fran.si/slovnice-in-pravopisi/14/1824-dajnko. Zadnja sprememba 10. 6. 2015.
The textbook is a grammar book written in German language and the first book written in the Dajnko alphabet (dajnčica) (Andoljšek, 1978, 329).

Vu sili pomoč na življenje rešenje zadušenih, vtopljenih, zmerznenih, obešenih, zadavlenih, ojadenih ino od bliska pobitih = Noth- und Hülfs- Tafel zur Lebensrettung der Erstickten, Ertrunkenen, Erfrornen, Erhängten, Erwürgten, Vergifteten und vom Blitze Getroffenen (1825)
Schmidt, Vlado: Zgodovina šolstva in pedagogike na Slovenskem II. (1805 - 1848). Ljubljana, Državna založba Slovenije, 1964, 212-213.

Schmidt emphasizes that the work was mainly intended for practical lessons for the rural youth. It is therefore not a textbook, yet at times such works were recommended for school use (Schmidt, 1964, 212-213).

Ilešič, Fran. O pouku slovenskega jezika : njega dosedanje smeri in bodoča naloga. V Ljubljani : Slovenska Šolska Matica, 1902, pp. 9, 24, 89-92; Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 90-93; Schmidt, Vlado. Zgodovina šolstva in pedagogike na Slovenskem I. Ljubljana : Delavska enotnost, 1988, pp. 236; Kidrič, Francè: Debevec, Janez (1758–1821). Slovenska biografija. Slovenska akademija znanosti in umetnosti, Znanstvenoraziskovalni center SAZU, 2013. https://www.slovenska-biografija.si/oseba/sbi170491/#slovenski-biografski-leksikon (29. July 2022). Originally published in: Slovenski bijografski leksikon: 1. vol. Abraham - Erberg. Izidor Cankar et al. Ljubljana, Zadružna gospodarska banka, 1925.

The work is probably no longer preserved. Regarding its fate, Andoljšek writes: 'Supposedly the only known copy was located in the National Museum of Slovenia in Ljubljana. It was borrowed by someone from Gimnazija Šentvid in Ljubljana and was destroyed there during the war.' In addition, it was probably not primarily intended for school lessons. As stated by Kidrič, 'His plateltof (primer), which was published 'with higher clearance' but not in the official stock of school books, was intended primarily for private lessons and autodidacts, because it brings completely new additions and formulations by D. and is less consistent with the alphabet that was prescribed for Austrian schools until 1794 than the alphabets from 1784, or 1790 and 1789 /.../.' The preface and paragraphs concerning the methodology are preserved in the transcript in Ilešič's work 'O pouku slovenskega jezika: njega dosedanje smeri in bodoča naloga' (Andoljšek, 1978, 90-93).
Nov popravleni plateltaf ali Bukve teh zherk, inu besedi : sa vsse kateri sè ozho Kransku brati is fundamenta vuzhiti (1794)

Nov popravleni plateltaf ali Bukve zherk, inu besedi sa vse katęri sè ozhjo Kransko brâti is sazhętka vuzhiti (1802); Plateltaf ali Bukve zherk, inu besedi sa vse, katęri se hozhejo Krajnsko brati is sazhętka vuzhiti (1805, 1808, 1814); Plateltaf ali Bukve zherk, inu bessedi sa vse, katęri se hozhejo Krajnsko brati is sazhętka vuzhiti (1815)

Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 66-72, 110-112; Schmidt, Vlado. Zgodovina šolstva in pedagogike na Slovenskem I. Ljubljana : Delavska enotnost, 1988, pp. 236-237.
The scope and content changed slightly (but not significantly) over time (Andoljšek, 1978, 66-72, 110-112).

V Ljubljani, Znanstveno društvo, 1930, 29; Andoljšek, Ivan: Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana, Univerzum, 1978, 59; Kidrič, Francè: Gutsman, Ožbald (1727–1790). Slovenska biografija. Slovenska akademija znanosti in umetnosti, Znanstvenoraziskovalni center SAZU, 2013. http://www.slovenska-biografija.si/oseba/sbi220945/#slovenski-biografski-leksikon (21. March 2022). Originally published in: Slovenski bijografski leksikon: 2. vol. Erberg - Hinterlechner. Izidor Cankar et al. Ljubljana, Zadružna gospodarska banka, 1926.

Regarding the purpose and use of the present work at school, Kidrič notes: 'The need for a book was discussed as early as 1777, 'in order to ease the efforts of catechism teachers in those parts of this country that are predominantly Slovenian'; it is a type whose Slovenian translation was given, as the case of Ahacelj shows, even in Carinthia, the lack of other Slovenian textbooks in the hands of schoolchildren, while the original was intended only for teachers and parents'. Kidrič believes that the work had already been printed before 1790, shortly after the translation of Veliki katekizem was commissioned in 1777 (in SBL Kidrič dates the supposed publication to around 1778). Andoljšek believes that this is not the case and places the first edition in the year 1790 (Kidrič, 2013 and Kidrič, 1929-1938, 198 and Andoljšek, 1978, 59).

Perhaps only Japelj's small catechism, which is part of the present work, could have been intended for school lessons, but Andoljšek points out that this is not very likely, and that the work 'cannot be considered a primary school textbook' (Andoljšek, 1978, 59).

Škafar points out that Kardoš 'partially /.../ adopted and reworked the texts from Bakoš and Barlo's book, mostly retranslating them from Hungarian.' Despite the fact that it is a hymnal, the work was also used for school lessons by both Kokolj and Horvat. The aforementioned authors also mention an edition printed in Graz from 1855, but we have not been able to identify it. As Škafar notes, it is very likely an error, which in this case is probably the result of summarizing Šlebinger's contribution about Kardoš from SBL (Škafar, 1978, 31-32, 51, 75 and Kokolj and Horvat, 1977, 121 and Šlebinger, 2013).

The first edition of this work was compiled in 1834 by Jožef Kek, while the second and third editions from 1843 and 1854 were 'provided by Jan Šlaker', who already participated in the first edition. Žigon, Almasy and Lovšin attribute an important role in the 1854 third edition to Franc Močnik. Later editions were 'extensively reproduced and corrected' by Andrej Praprotnik. The 1898 edition, which was published after Praprotnik's death, was 'extensively multiplied and corrected by Jakob Dimnik' (Lesar, 2013 and Žigon and Almasy and Lovšin, 2017, 103-104).

April 2023)

The work was republished in 1923. Matej Hriberšek comments that the book goes beyond the scope of recommended reading (in accordance with reform tendencies) because, in addition to the established six biographies (Miltiades, Themistocles, Aristides, Cimon, Epaminondas, Pelopidas), he added five more: of Pausanias, Lysander, Thrasybulus, Agesilaus and Hamilcar. He chose nine of the most famous passages from the life of Alexander the Great from Curci Rufus (Hriberšek, 2005, 189, 317).

It is a 'partially adapted' variant of Slomšek's work Blaže in Nežica v nedeljski šoli. The work is a textbook in the most general sense of the word. Škafar calls it an 'educational book', while Kokolj and Horvat describe it as a work intended for 'students of Sunday schools, schools for adults as well as teachers as a guide and a collection of teaching material' (Škafar, 1978, 30 and Andoljšek, 1978, 191-192 and Kokolj and Horvat 1977, 130-132).

Szvéti evangyeliomi pouleg kalendárioma, i reda rimszkoga na vsze nedelne, i szvétesnye dni z-obcsinszkoga szvetoga piszma po zapouvidi nyih goszposztva, i náj visse postüvanoga goszpouda Szily Jánosa, z-Gornyega Szopora, szombotelszkoga püspeka, na sztari szlovenszki jezik, po postüvanom goszpoudi Küzmics Miklósi, Szvétoga Benedeka fare dühovniki, ino Okrogline szlovenszke vice-öspörössa obrnyeni, i sztroskom onoga nyih goszposztva püspeka vö zostampani. Despite the fact that the work was not conceived as a textbook, it served this purpose, especially in earlier periods - as Kokolj and Horvat point out, especially as a reader. The second and third editions were published in 1804. The work was published after 1920 (Škafar, 1978, 22-23 and Kokolj and Horvat, 1977, 72-73).

COBISS also lists an edition from the UKM dated 'before 1859'. This is certainly true, but we can certainly place the work a little further back in time. As Škafar points out, Alojys Weitzinger died on September 25, 1844. Given that the present copy still mentions Aloys, but not his son and successor Johann Albert, we can definitely place the issue before September 25, 1844. The work was revised in 1864 by Vendelin Ratkovič and Jožef Borovnjak (Škafar, 1978, 30 and Novak, 2013 and Krajnc Vrečko, 2013 and Šlebinger, 2013).

The work was reprinted at least 24 times. The editions that were printed from 1904 were revised by Jožef Sakovič. Regarding the school use of the present text, which of course was not primarily intended as a school textbook, Andoljšek writes: 'Knigi molitveni (1783) /…/ were added songs, translated from the official Teresian hymnal, and they represent the beginning of the printed Catholic hymnals of Prekmurje and were used in Catholic schools precisely because of them' (Škafar, 1978, 70-71, 74, 77, 78-79, 84 and Andoljšek, 1978, 61 and Novak, 2013).

Before 1871, two editions of the present work, which cannot be precisely dated, were published in Radgona by the same publisher under different titles. Despite the significant change in the title, it is a reworking of the present text by Küzmič, also in the case of the work  'Krátki krsztsánszki návuk za málo deczo' published in 1895. Thus Škafar comments: 'Actually, the fifteenth edition of M. Küzmič's Slovenian syllabary from 1780, only without the alphabet and examples of syllabification /…. - The editor is unknown' (Škafar, 1978, 45-46, 62).

Györszki Kátekismus tou-je-tou: D. Luther Mártonna Máli Kátekismus, z drügimi lejpimi pobo`snimi pítanyami, ino szem szpodobnimi nísterimi molitvami, zdaj znouvics Na Szlovenszko obrnyen, za volo, v-Szlovenszkoj Okroglini L. Solszke Deczé (1796)

Škafar, Ivan: Bibliografija prekmurskih tiskov od 1715 do 1919 = Bibliographie der Drucke im Dialekt von Prekmurje von 1715 bis 1919. Ljubljana, Slovenska akademija znanosti in umetnosti, 1978, 15, 21.

As Škafar points out, it is a revised edition of Temlin's work 'Mali katechismus, touje tou krátki návuk vöre kerschánszke' (a translation and adaptation of the 'Hungarian translation of Luther's Small Catechism') from 1715. The author of the present revision is unknown. As the most likely candidate Škafar cites Mihal Bakoš (Škafar, 1978, 15, 21).

Metelko's translation of the German calculus 'Anleitung zur Rechenkunst zum Gebrauche der deutschen Schulen in den kaiserlichen königlichen Staaten. Erster Theil. Für Trivial- und Hauptschulen von drey Classen' was not very widespread in schools with the Slovenian language of instruction. Thus Schmidt comments: 'In one and a half years, only 17 copies were sold, even though first-grade students could also use it. In bilingual schools, they used German calculus, but in Slovenian schools - as in most cases before - due to the predominantly oral calculus, they also published without it, especially since it was printed in the Metelko alphabet' (Hladnik, 2017, 314 in Schmidt, 1964, 223-224).

Before 1871, two editions of the present work, which cannot be precisely dated, were published in Bad Radkersburg by the same publisher under different titles. Despite the significant change in the title, it is a reworking of the present text by Küzmič, also in the case of the work Krátki krsztsánszki návuk za málo deczo' published in 1895. Škafar states: 'In reality, the 15th edition of M. Küzmič's Slovenski silabikar from 1780, only without the alphabet and examples of syllabification /…. - The editor is unknown' (Škafar, 1978, 45-46, 62).

Regarding the diffusion of the work, Schmidt points out that: 'in Carniola /.../ in the first years after publication, the deaneries, which also had a main school on their territory, received barely a few thousand copies of the first German reader per year, i.e., even less than bilingual grammar books, although the reading compositions were supposed to be used as reading exercises for grammar books.' (Schmidt, 1988, 284) Regarding the other authors who were involved in the creation of this and other Močnik's works, see: (Žigon and Almasy and Lovšin, 2017, 103-104).

Regarding the authorship, Schmidt writes that the royalties 'were shared between Blaž Potočnik and Franc Močnik.' The work was intended especially for classes in the fourth grade of the major schools (Hauptschulen) in Carniola. In practice, according to Schmidt, the work was used 'mainly for learning German language' (Schmidt, 1988, 283).

The textbook was approved by the ministry on October 4, 1868, No. 8204, thus Andoljšek assumes that the textbook was also published in that year (Andoljšek, 1978, 252). However, given the confirmation date, it is quite possible that it was not actually printed until the following year. Neither the edition from 1868 nor 1869 is available in Slovenian libraries. However, since the edition from 1869 (from the Library of Congress) is accessible via the Internet and is not mentioned by Andoljšek or other literature, we assume that it is the same edition, thus we entered 1869 as the first year of its publication.

Despite the changes in the titles, it is the same textbook, and only a few texts have been added over the years. Andoljšek lists the editions from 1882, 1885, 1890, 1891, 1893, and 1902, but mentions that the literature also mentions the editions of 1887 and 1888. The problem is that in this case the counting of reprints printed in textbooks is incorrect (Andoljšek, 1976, 133 -134). The COBISS system also includes the 1888 edition, which is why it is still included in the list, as well as the unmentioned 1901 edition.

In its entirety, the textbook was published only twice (1854 and 1868) and several times in parts:  I. Dogodivščina svete vere (Ks. Kosar), II. Navod pobožnega življenja in lepega zadržanja (according to bishop Bernard Galur, Felicijan Globočnik), III. Spisovanje listov (Matia Majer), IV. Številoslovje (supposedly S. according to Krajnc's draft), V. Vodba modrega kmetovanja (Peter Musi), VI. Vinoreja (Anton Koderman), VII. Zemljopis (Jožef Drobnič), VIII. Ljubezen do domovine (Slomšek) (Andoljšek, 1978, 270).

Ljubljana, Slovenska akademija znanosti in umetnosti, 1960; Karin Almasy, Kanon und nationale Konsolidierung. Übersetzungen und ideologische Steuerung in slowenischen Schullesebüchern (1848–1918), pp. 264-265, 390. Wien: Böhlau, 2018, https://library.oapen.org/handle/20.500.12657/25718;

Both Cobiss and dLib.si attribute the authorship to Jožef Rozman, which Andoljšek as well as Ivan Grafenauer and Alfonz Gspan (Grafenauer and Gspan, 2013) reject. The author of the work is said to be Slomšek (Andoljšek, 1978, 259). At the same time, Almasy points out that Rozman was then a young seminarian who was part of Slomšek's circle. Slomšek was supposed to take over the editing and final design, leaving the writing mainly to younger people (Almasy, 2018, 390).

Strictly speaking, the work is not a textbook, but it nevertheless also served as lessons for schoolchildren. Bakoš himself recommended the work for such use in the preface (Kokolj and Horvat, 1977, 92). In addition, the work was also considered in agriculture lessons in review schools (Schmidt, 1988, 92, 336).

The translation of the New Testament is the work of Mikloš Küzmič. As Škafar notes, the editions from 1848 and 1883 were 'linguistically edited by Aleksander Terplan'. Terplan's translation of the Psalms is also added to the latter. Only the first edition contains also a comprehensive foreword by Jožef Torkoš. As Kokolj and Hrovat point out, the present text was used as a reader in schools. The work was published in 1928 (Škafar, 1978, 17, 24, 32, 54-55 and Kokolj and Horvat, 1977, 122 and Šlebinger, 2013 and Novak, 2013 and Novak, 2013).

Regarding the authorship of the present work, Schmidt writes: 'The first part of the small reader (catechism) was translated by Ravnikar in 1819, but it was published as a primary school book in Carniola only in 1834 under the title 'Keršanski katolški nauk za male šole na kmetih...' in 'Zaloga šolskih knjig na Dunaju' (Schmidt, 1964, 204).

April 2023).

The compiler of the present work was Andrej Zamejic. From 1889, the standard version coexisted and was published simultaneously with a substantially more comprehensive revised edition; the latter was published in 1889, 1890, 1893 and 1896. Both versions were approved and at the same time allowed for use in school classes. In the present entry, we combine both (Smolik, 2013).

April 2023); Verordnungsblatt für den Dienstbereich des Ministeriums für Cultus und Unterricht, no. 12 (1896), 315. https://alex.onb.ac.at/cgi-content/alex?aid=vcu&datum=1896&size=45&page=349 (6. April 2023).

Given that the work is listed in the list of approved textbooks for elementary schools (Volksschulen) as early as 1878, there are certainly earlier prints, but we have not been able to identify them so far. From 1889, the standard version coexisted and was published simultaneously with a more extensive revised edition, the latter was published at least in 1889. In 1896, a slightly shorter 'revised edition' was published. All variants were approved and simultaneously approved for use in school lessons.

Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 66; Ilešič, Fran. O pouku slovenskega jezika : njega dosedanje smeri in bodoča naloga. V Ljubljani : Slovenska Šolska Matica, 1902, pp. 25.

Andoljšek did not review the work, and only mentions it indirectly. Considering that the title is very similar and the publisher is the same, it is probably not impossible that it is an earlier version of Debevec's work. However, the two parts differ significantly in the number of pages. As the work has not yet been digitized, I cannot verify this for the time being. In any event, the work kept in the library of the National Museum of Slovenia will have to be reviewed.

Abecednik za šole na kmétih (1850)
Digitalna knjižnica Slovenije - dLib.si: https://www.dlib.si/?URN=urn:nbn:si:doc-z4q034nu; Zgodovina Slovenije - SIstory: https://hdl.handle.net/11686/51396
Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 166.

Andoljšek notes that it is a 'translation of Marchner's Alphabet.' The Trieste 1850 edition differs slightly from the two Vienna editions. It also contains a brief explanation of the differences between Gaj's Latin Alphabet and Bohorič Alphabet, however minor differences can also be found in the language. Andoljšek states: 'While in the Vienna editions the words have suffixes -om, -ega, -ik, in the Trieste edition they have suffixes -am, -iga, -ek' (Andoljšek, 1978, 166). The second edition has an extended first part (alphabet and basic grammar, while the texts do not differ). Both versions are digitized.

It is a repeatedly translated/adapted German reader 'Kleine Erzählungen zum Gebrauche der Landschulen in den kaiserl. königl. Staaten' which was translated by Matevž Ravnikar as Male povesti, Janez Debevec as Majhine perpovedanja, Štefan Kociančič as Povestice za pervo začetno šolo (Andoljšek, 1978, 277), and Jurij Alič as Kratke povésti. Debevec's translation served as the basis for Ravnikar's. Two different readers were published, 'Male povésti : sa şhole na kmétih po zesarskih kraljévih deshélah' and 'Male povéşti : sa méstine shole po zesarskih kraljévih deshélah.' Andoljšek believes that there are almost no significant differences in content between the two editions, and he considers the two titles out of place (Andoljšek, 1978, 192). Andoljšek does not mention the Viennese editions.

ABC bukvize sa Slovenze : taku dobru sa te odsrashene, koker te maihine otroke : kateri se brati navuzhiti shelijo (1810)
Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 137-138.

Regarding the nature of the present work, Andoljšek writes: 'The unofficial ABC bukvice (1810) are only a slightly corrected plateltaf (reader) from Felbiger's era. The booklet contains 10 pages of the alphabet, 20 pages of religious reading only, and on page 31 there is a multiplication table 1 to 10' (Andoljšek, 1978, 137).
Nov popravleni plateltaf ali Bukve teh zherk inu besedi : sa usse kateri sé ozhjo Krajnsku brâti is fundamenta vuzhiti (between 1787 and 1814)
Nov popravlieni plateltaf ali Bukve teh zherk inu besedi : sa usse kateri se ozhjo Krajnsku brati is fundamenta vuzhiti (18--)
Andoljšek, Ivan. Naš začetni bralni pouk in učbeniki zanj I (1550-1869). Ljubljana : Univerzum, 1978, pp. 138.

In connection with it and its relationship with Debevč's text, Andoljšek writes: 'Probably before 1814, the Slovenian unofficial Nov popravleni plateltaf or bekve teh cherk inu worde was published by Jožef Merzinger in Maribor. /.../ 'Nov popravleni plateltaf' is almost just like Debevec's 'Nov popravleni plateltaf' from 1794, only that it is linguistically different and contains a lot of printing errors' (Andoljšek, 1978, 138).

Ljubljana, Delavska enotnost, 1988, 285; Verordnungsblatt für den Dienstbereich des Ministeriums für Cultus und Unterricht, no. 11 (1887), 126. https://alex.onb.ac.at/cgi-content/alex?aid=vcu&datum=1887&size=45&page=150 (6. May 2023).

Vlado Schmidt places the first edition in 1868, but we have not been able to find a copy of the book. COBISS lists editions from 1871, 1875, 1877, 1879, 1881, 1882, 1883, 1884, 1886, 1889. A comparison of the digitized editions (1871 and 1879) shows that there were significant content changes in the newer editions. But considering that they were all published by the same publisher and in the same location, it can still be concluded that it is the same textbook.

Navk sa ludi na kmetih, tistim shivlenje odtéti, katiri so se zadushili, vtonili, smersnili, obésli ali sadavli, katiri so strup vshili, od strele pobiti in pre sgodaj rojeni (1817)
Schmidt, Vlado: Zgodovina šolstva in pedagogike na Slovenskem II. (1805 - 1848). Ljubljana, Državna založba Slovenije, 1964, 212-213.

Schmidt emphasizes that the work was mainly intended for practical lessons for the rural youth. It is therefore not a textbook, yet at times such works were recommended for school use (Schmidt, 1964, 212-213).
